I had no idea their shells were that sensitive. Pretty good piece of info 
to have. ﻿
top_comment.author: BringBacktheHitch

comments.author: Rochester Oliveira

comments.text:
+Rochester Oliveira
It's interesting.  I had two pet turtles, and I'd rub their shells and 
something very gently clean them, but I never knocked on them.  I never 
realized though that they were that sensitive.  It did occur to me that 
they could feel it pretty well though.  When I rubbed them, they'd shut 
their eyes and lull their heads a bit.  It was cute, and I could easily 
tell it wasn't a painful thing to them but rather pleasurable.
comments.author: Raidfreak

comments.text:

comments.text:

Lesson learned. Do not knock on tortoises' shells.

comments.text: Indeed, I have a pet turtle myself and would never guess that!

comments.text:
+PJ Jama
Dude, look. I'm not sure to what extent you were originally joking, but 
you've got to understand, a lot of female youtubers experience a lot of 
really creepy comments. I think, as people in a community, it's our job to 
create a place where such comments are unwelcome. I'm not trying to 
compensate for my inadequacy here, I'm just trying to say a lot of people 
on Youtube do read the comments on their videos, and even if you were not 
even 1% serious, given the frequency of creepiness on Youtube, it's 
probably best to phrase your comments a little more sensitively.
comments.author: Gabriel de Sousa

top_comment.text:
That's really something how her digestion preserves and packages the seeds 
she eats, but what I'd like to know is why? Is it a coincidence that her 
digestion works like that-one which happens by chance to be beneficial to 
seeds-or does treating the seeds so well somehow provide her with an 
adaptive advantage? ﻿
top_comment.author: Cary Cocuzzi

comments.text:
An evolutionist would call it an example of mutualism. The plants that 
produce fruits tortises like get better seed dispersial, the tortises that 
take the right size bites get more food producing plamts.
comments.author: David Bunner

comments.text:
This is just a guess, but my thoughts are there is some kind of coating, or 
the outside shell of the seed can't be digested.
comments.author: Drew Heskett

comments.author: Satisfyedeyes

top_comment.text:
I have a question: you mentioned that Yucca is very social but what kind of 
interspecies socializing can reptiles do? Would a snake befriend a lizard? 
And why would they socialize interspecies in the first place?
Also, you mentioned multiple times that the tortoise enjoys a certain 
behaviour like strolling around or being touched on a specific spot, but 
how exactly do you know that it does 'enjoy' that? What do you mean when 
you say "enjoyment"? I assume it doesn't behave like social mammals with 
frequent reinforcing or warning gestures, but I may be wrong. Can you give 
examples what a tortoise does when it enjoys something (maybe something 
similar to cats purr or dogs tail movement).﻿
top_comment.author: Caner Turan

comments.text:
+inkling139 is right on! Red foots are very social tortoises. Others can be 
as well but it's more of an individual thing rather than a species thing. I 
can tell Yucca likes or dislikes a certain external stimuli by observing 
her behavior in response to that stimuli. She wasn't really "into" the 
shell rub while we were filming, but usually she will stop and push herself 
into the rub like inkling139 described Tortellini does :)

You did point out something I'd like to touch on in a video though, and 
that is anthropomorphising. We always need to be careful when we discuss 
animal behavior so we don't label their actions in human emotional terms. I 
can observe that Yucca "enjoys" being rubbed on the back of her shell 
because she reacts by encouraging and attempting to have me repeat my 
actions by following me around and trying to engage me if I stop.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text: +inkling139 Best tortoise name ever.
comments.author: bojandude

comments.text:
While I'm not Jessie I do have a Red Footed Tortoise so maybe I can help 
answer some of your questions. I can't speak for inter-reptile 
socialization but I know Red Foots are very social with humans. Whenever my 
girl, Tortellini, sees me outside her enclosure she hurries over to say hi. 
If I open the door she does her best to climb over the lip of the cage and 
into my lap. Even when I pull her out and set her on the ground, sometimes 
she'll explore but usually she likes to hang out right by me. She'll even 
ignore her freshly filled food bowl at times because she'd rather get some 
attention. Many types of tortoises are like this with their owners but tend 
to get territorial with other tortoises, Red Foots are an exception and 
will frequently get along with other Red Foots sharing their enclosure. 
Hopefully that gives you an idea on how social they can be, as to why, I 
think it gives them something interesting to do. Interaction with another 
creature is more interesting then being by yourself, especially if it's a 
human that tends to give you tasty food or shell scratches. And yes, they 
absolutely love getting their shell scratched in certain spots, 
particularly around the back end (like Jessie demonstrated) and around the 
front. Mine will stop whatever she's doing, press into my hand, and dance 
from foot to foot, rubbing her shell back and forth. I'm guessing Yucca 
usually does the same (many do) she just wasn't feeling up to demonstrating 
in the video. I frequently use a toothbrush instead of my fingers/nails and 
then she'll really dance against it. If she wasn't enjoying it then she'd 
either give no reaction or walk away. It feels good to them though because 
the areas between their scutes is where new shell growth is added and new 
growth tends to be itchy. Since a tortoise can reach around and scratch 
their shell themselves they need to find something to rub against. As for 
reinforcing or warning gestures, typically if they like something they will 
stop whatever they're doing (walking, sleeping, eating) and hurry as fast 
as their little legs can carry them over to what they want, bulldozing over 
anything in their way. If they don't like something they'll either walk 
away or pull into their shells, making a hissing noise as they quickly 
exhale all the air in their lungs to make room like Jessie said. Hope that 
helps!
comments.author: inkling139

captions.text:
Hey guys we're at Animal Wonders, and I am
super excited because we're on this awesome

new adventure creating awesome content with
a little help from our friends.

Today I'm really excited to share with you
some behind the scenes stuff. That's really
hard to say - behind the scenes stuff!

So a little bit about how Animal Wonders runs
is we have three separate rooms for each large

category of animals at Animal Wonders. Um,
we have about 80 animals, and so we wanted
to keep each of them at their optimum temperature.

Now, we didn't want to create 80 different
environments, so we grouped them into three

relatively similar categories and then we
make adjustments as we go.
(Upbeat music)

So, we have the mammal room which is right
behind you. We have the reptile room right

here, and we have the bird room right here.
Each one of them is uniquely temperature regulated,

each one is uniquely noisy, and each one is
uniquely smelly!
Let's visit the reptile room!

Meet the keeper of the reptile room! Yucca
the red-footed tortoise is everything you

could ask for in a watch tortoise. She marches,
she patrols, she watches - nothing escapes
her keen Chelonian eyes.

Actually tortoise eyesight hasn't been thoroughly
studied. It is thought that they're good at

seeing general colours and objects, but that
their detailed vision isn't as developed.

Many tortoises have color preferences. Yucca
really likes reds and oranges; that could
just be because those are her favourite fruits.

Yucca is a red-footed tortoise that lives
in the rainforest of South America. She's

gonna get to live around 80 years and she'll
be between 30 and 40 pounds.

You can find her wandering around the forest
floors looking for fallen fruit and other

vegetation, and when she finds one she's going
to take a really big bite of it; she's not

going to chew. She can take a bite of it and
swallow it whole. She's going to consume it

pretty slowly. This form of consumption allows
seeds to remain intact, and so when she does

finally eliminate it, it's going to be dispersed
from its original location, and it's going

to be packaged with this nice little goody
bag of nutrients so it has a great start in
life.

Look how pretty she is! I like to compliment
her 'cause she's really sensitive. No, not

emotionally sensitive - she is sense of touch
sensitive though! Tortoises can actually feel

everything through their shell; at one time
it was common for people to be really, really

rough on their shells, like they would go
so far as to recommend drilling holes in their

shell to tether them to places. And that'd
be like drilling a hole through your tooth
without anaesthetic.

I'm sure most people that care about animals
have enough common sense to not drill through

their pet's shell, but this little history
lesson just goes to show how important research

in the animals behavior, their anatomy, and
physiology can be so that we all know it's

common knowledge not to drill through a tortoise's
shell.

People today still think that it's okay to
knock on Yucca's shell - I mean, who does

that? Are you going to go up to a dog and
knock on their head or a cat or a hamster
or a person? Don't knock on tortoise's shells.

Yucca actually has a favorite spot to be touched.
Kind of like a dog likes its tail pet, she

likes right here-here, right here pet. She
loves this; we could just do this all day.

The TARDIS shell is bigger on the inside - no
really, it's actually pretty snug in there.

When they get scared they're going to pull
their heads inside and then cover their heads

with their arms like that, but in order to
fit their head inside they have to exhale
all the air in their lungs.

Now when we humans exhale, we almost immediately
want to inhale again because the CO2 builds

up in there, but tortoises are much more tolerant
of the CO2 buildup, so that's going to allow

them to hold their breath for much longer
periods and stay safe from predators.

The same mechanism works for turtles when
they're doing their deep sea dives. So the

reptile room is a nice toasty 85 degrees during
the day, and 75 at night, and that keeps most

of our herps in a good natural range with
a few exceptions. Yucca's really happy with

the temperature. In the wild she would work
to maintain her own temperature by going into

the sun or the shade or by little pores in
her shell, which is covered by scutes.

These tiny pores in the scutes help with thermoregulation
by effectively trapping in radiant heat. Yucca

outgrew every enclosure that we got her, so
we just decided that we're just going to give

her the run of the reptile room. It works
out 'cause she's really social and she loves

to be involved in everything we're doing;
like right now she's climbing underneath me.
(End music)

What was the tortoise doing on the highway?
About 100 millimeters an hour! (laughs)
